hints.title: Cloning-Scutoid Correspondence
hints.content:
405: :label: thm-cloning-scutoid-correspondence
406: 
407: Let $e_i$ be an episode of the Fragile Gas with:
408: - Birth time $t_i^{\text{birth}}$ at position $x_i^{\text{birth}}$
409: - Death time $t_i^{\text{death}}$ at position $x_i^{\text{death}}$
410: - Parent episode $e_j$ (if $i$ is a cloned episode)
411: 
412: Define the **neighbor set** of episode $i$ at time $t$ as:
413: 
414: $$
415: \mathcal{N}_i(t) = \{k \in \mathcal{A}(t) : \text{Vor}_k(t) \cap \text{Vor}_i(t) \neq \emptyset\}
416: $$
417: 
418: (the set of walkers whose Voronoi cells share a boundary with walker $i$'s Voronoi cell).
419: 
420: **Statement**: A cloning event at time $t_{\text{clone}}$ (where episode $e_i$ dies and is replaced by a child episode $e_{i'}$ cloned from episode $e_j$) induces a **neighbor topology change**:
421: 
422: $$
423: \mathcal{N}_{i'}(t_{\text{clone}}^+) \neq \mathcal{N}_i(t_{\text{clone}}^-)
424: $$
425: 
426: where $t^-$ denotes the instant before cloning and $t^+$ denotes the instant after.
427: 
428: **Geometric consequence**: The spacetime volume connecting:
429: - Bottom face: $\text{Vor}_i(t_{\text{clone}}^-)$ (neighbors $\mathcal{N}_i(t^-)$)
430: - Top face: $\text{Vor}_{i'}(t_{\text{clone}}^+)$ (neighbors $\mathcal{N}_{i'}(t^+)$)
431: 
432: **must be a scutoid** (not a prism), because the neighbor sets differ, forcing the existence of mid-level vertices where geodesic rulings branch.

hints.label: unlabeled-proof-38
hints.content:
437: :::{prf:proof}
438: 
439: **Part 1: Cloning induces neighbor change with probability 1**
440: 
441: Consider a cloning event where walker $i$ at position $x_i \in \mathcal{X}$ is replaced by a clone of walker $j$ at position $x_j \in \mathcal{X}$ with $x_i \neq x_j$.
442: 
443: **Setup**: Let $S^{(t^-)} = \{x_1, \ldots, x_N\}$ be the walker positions before cloning, where walker $i$ is at $x_i$. After cloning, walker $i$ is replaced by a new walker at position:
444: 
445: $$
446: x_{i'} = x_j + \xi, \quad \xi \sim \mathcal{N}(0, \sigma_x^2 I)
447: $$
448: 
449: The new configuration is $S^{(t^+)} = \{x_1, \ldots, x_{i-1}, x_{i'}, x_{i+1}, \ldots, x_N\}$.
450: 
451: **Voronoi neighbor condition**: Walker $k$ is a neighbor of walker $i$ if and only if their Voronoi cells share a boundary:
452: 
453: $$
454: k \in \mathcal{N}_i \iff \exists p \in \mathcal{X}: d_g(p, x_k) = d_g(p, x_i) < d_g(p, x_\ell) \text{ for all } \ell \neq i, k
455: $$
456: 
457: **Key claim**: For any fixed $k \in \mathcal{N}_i(t^-)$ with $k \neq j$, the probability that $k \in \mathcal{N}_{i'}(t^+)$ vanishes as $\|x_i - x_j\| \to \infty$.
458: 
459: **Proof of claim**: The Voronoi boundary between cells $k$ and $i$ consists of points equidistant to $x_k$ and $x_i$. For $k$ to also be a neighbor of $i'$ at $x_{i'} = x_j + \xi$, there must exist a point $p$ equidistant to both $x_k$ and $x_{i'}$:
460: 
461: $$
462: d_g(p, x_k) = d_g(p, x_j + \xi)
463: $$
464: 
465: For large $\|x_i - x_j\|$, the sets $\{p : d_g(p, x_k) = d_g(p, x_i)\}$ and $\{p : d_g(p, x_k) = d_g(p, x_j)\}$ are **disjoint hypersurfaces** in $\mathcal{X}$ (generically), separated by distance $O(\|x_i - x_j\|)$. The Gaussian jitter $\xi$ with variance $\sigma_x^2$ cannot bridge this gap with high probability.
466: 
467: **Measure-theoretic statement**: Let $P_{\text{preserve}}(k; x_i, x_j)$ be the probability that neighbor $k \in \mathcal{N}_i(t^-)$ remains a neighbor after cloning ($k \in \mathcal{N}_{i'}(t^+)$). Then:
468: 
469: $$
470: P_{\text{preserve}}(k; x_i, x_j) \to 0 \quad \text{as } \|x_i - x_j\| \to \infty
471: $$
472: 
473: Since cloning can occur between any two walkers (Chapter 3), and the fitness-based selection does not constrain their spatial separation, neighbor-changing cloning events have **positive measure** in the space of algorithm trajectories.
474: 
475: **Conclusion**: $\mathbb{P}(\mathcal{N}_{i'}(t^+) \neq \mathcal{N}_i(t^-)) > 0$ for cloning events, and for spatially distant cloning ($\|x_i - x_j\| \gg \sigma_x$), the probability approaches 1.
476: 
477: **Part 2: Neighbor change forces scutoid geometry (using boundary correspondence map)**
478: 
479: Now suppose $\mathcal{N}_i(t^-) \neq \mathcal{N}_{i'}(t^+)$. By Definition {prf:ref}`def-neighbor-segments`, decompose the Voronoi boundaries:
480: 
481: $$
482: \partial \text{Vor}_i(t^-) = \bigcup_{k \in \mathcal{N}_i(t^-)} \Gamma_{i,k}(t^-)
483: $$
484: 
485: $$
486: \partial \text{Vor}_{i'}(t^+) = \bigcup_{\ell \in \mathcal{N}_{i'}(t^+)} \Gamma_{i',\ell}(t^+)
487: $$
488: 
489: Define the shared and non-shared neighbor sets:
490: - $\mathcal{N}_{\text{shared}} = \mathcal{N}_i(t^-) \cap \mathcal{N}_{i'}(t^+)$
491: - $\mathcal{N}_{\text{lost}} = \mathcal{N}_i(t^-) \setminus \mathcal{N}_{i'}(t^+)$ (neighbors lost)
492: - $\mathcal{N}_{\text{gained}} = \mathcal{N}_{i'}(t^+) \setminus \mathcal{N}_i(t^-)$ (neighbors gained)
493: 
494: By Definition {prf:ref}`def-boundary-correspondence`, the boundary correspondence map $\phi_k$ is **well-defined** only for $k \in \mathcal{N}_{\text{shared}}$. For $\ell \in \mathcal{N}_{\text{lost}}$, there is **no segment** $\Gamma_{i',\ell}(t^+)$ to map to, so $\phi_\ell$ is **undefined**.
495: 
496: **Topological necessity of mid-level structure**: To construct a continuous spacetime volume connecting $\text{Vor}_i(t^-) \times \{t^-\}$ to $\text{Vor}_{i'}(t^+) \times \{t^+\}$, we must connect every boundary segment at the bottom to a corresponding segment at the top.
497: 
498: For $k \in \mathcal{N}_{\text{shared}}$: The segment $\Gamma_{i,k}(t^-)$ maps via $\phi_k$ to $\Gamma_{i',k}(t^+)$, and the lateral face $\Sigma_k$ is constructed by geodesic ruling (Definition {prf:ref}`def-riemannian-scutoid`, item 4).
499: 
500: For $\ell \in \mathcal{N}_{\text{lost}}$: The segment $\Gamma_{i,\ell}(t^-)$ has **no image** under any correspondence map $\phi$. To close the volume's boundary, this segment's geodesic ruling must **terminate** at an intermediate location in spacetime.
501: 
502: For $m \in \mathcal{N}_{\text{gained}}$: The segment $\Gamma_{i',m}(t^+)$ has **no preimage** under any correspondence map. Its geodesic ruling must **originate** from an intermediate location.
503: 
504: **Definition of mid-level vertices**: The points in spacetime where geodesics from lost neighbors terminate and geodesics to gained neighbors originate are the **mid-level vertices**. Their existence is **topologically necessary** to form a closed boundary when $\mathcal{N}_{\text{lost}} \cup \mathcal{N}_{\text{gained}} \neq \emptyset$.
505: 
506: By Definition {prf:ref}`def-riemannian-scutoid`, this is precisely a scutoid (not a prism). $\square$
507: 
508: **Part 3: No cloning implies prism**
509: 
510: If no cloning occurs, walker $i$ persists from $t^-$ to $t^+$. The position changes via Langevin dynamics:
511: 
512: $$
513: x_i(t^+) = x_i(t^-) + v_i \Delta t + \text{noise}
514: $$
515: 
516: The Voronoi cell $\text{Vor}_i(t)$ evolves continuously. For small $\Delta t$, the neighbor set $\mathcal{N}_i(t)$ changes continuously, meaning $\mathcal{N}_i(t^+) = \mathcal{N}_i(t^-)$ (up to boundary events, which are measure-zero).
517: 
518: If neighbors are unchanged, the boundary segments on top and bottom match one-to-one, so the lateral faces are ruled surfaces without branching. This is a **prism** (or frustum if the cell size changes, but with same topology).

hints.label: cor-scutoid-fraction
hints.title: Scutoid Fraction as Cloning Rate Proxy
hints.content:
524: :label: cor-scutoid-fraction
525: 
526: The **fraction of scutoid cells** in the spacetime tessellation is:
527: 
528: $$
529: \phi(t) = \frac{\text{Number of scutoids in } [t, t + \Delta t]}{\text{Number of cells (episodes) in } [t, t + \Delta t]}
530: $$
531: 
532: This is asymptotically equal to the **cloning rate** of the algorithm:
533: 
534: $$
535: \phi(t) \approx p_{\text{clone}}(t) = \frac{\text{Number of cloning events in } [t, t + \Delta t]}{N}
536: $$
537: 
538: where $N$ is the total number of walkers.

hints.label: def-cell-type-taxonomy
hints.title: Cell Type Taxonomy
hints.content:
557: :label: def-cell-type-taxonomy
558: 
559: Spacetime cells in the scutoid tessellation are classified by their **topological complexity**:
560: 
561: 1. **Prism (Type 0)**: No mid-level vertices, same neighbors at top and bottom
562:    - $|\mathcal{N}(t^+) \cap \mathcal{N}(t^-)| = |\mathcal{N}(t^-)| = |\mathcal{N}(t^+)|$
563:    - Corresponds to: **persistent walker** (no cloning)
564:    - Geometric phase: Exploitation, convergence
565: 
566: 2. **Simple scutoid (Type 1)**: One mid-level vertex
567:    - $|\mathcal{N}(t^+) \setminus \mathcal{N}(t^-)| = 1$ and $|\mathcal{N}(t^-) \setminus \mathcal{N}(t^+)| = 1$
568:    - Corresponds to: **single cloning event** (one neighbor gained, one lost)
569:    - Geometric phase: Adaptive exploration
570: 
571: 3. **Complex scutoid (Type k)**: $k$ mid-level vertices
572:    - Multiple neighbors gained/lost
573:    - Corresponds to: **multiple simultaneous cloning events** or rapid neighbor turnover
574:    - Geometric phase: Chaotic exploration, phase transition

hints.label: prop-euler-characteristic-scutoid
hints.title: Euler Characteristic and Scutoid Index
hints.content:
580: :label: prop-euler-characteristic-scutoid
581: 
582: The **Euler characteristic** of a scutoid cell $\mathcal{S}$ is related to its scutoid index $\chi_{\text{scutoid}}$ by:
583: 
584: $$
585: \chi(\mathcal{S}) = \chi(F_{\text{top}}) + \chi(F_{\text{bottom}}) - \chi_{\text{scutoid}}
586: $$
587: 
588: where $\chi(F)$ is the Euler characteristic of the face $F$ (e.g., $\chi(\text{polygon}) = 1$).
589: 
590: **Proof sketch**: Each mid-level vertex creates a branching in the edge graph, which reduces the Euler characteristic by altering the vertex-edge-face balance in the Euler formula $V - E + F = \chi$.
591: 
592: **Consequence**: The Euler characteristic of the entire tessellation at time $t$ is:
593: 
594: $$
595: \chi(\mathcal{T}_t) = N_{\text{cells}} - \sum_{\text{cells}} \chi_{\text{scutoid}}
596: $$
